ratings.question_text: Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
comments: Combination of pre-recorded videos and virtual discussion.
Combination virtual discussion and work time (done offline and online, but all remotely)

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: How to work with diverse materials (cardboard, alginate, foam, plaster)
I developed a variety of sculpting techniques and learned about a variety of art theory and history.
Appreciation of public art, understanding of intentionality behind choice of material and location in creating a sculpture, contextual awareness of art

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Strenths: knowledgeable professor and TF, and an intimate work environment. Weaknesses: difficulty to connect as a class and fully experience sculpting due to the Zoom format.

Elizabeth and Stella did a fantastic job transitioning sculpture basics online! As someone who gets stir-crazy in in-person studio classes, the online format they utilized was the best of both worlds for me great advice and discussion from the instructors and peers, but the ability to work in my own space. It would be great if students could have had access to workspaces and maker spaces within the school, but I know Elizabeth and Stella advocated on our behalf for these things.
great immediate feedback from professor/ta and my peers, peer critique of sculptures was great, projects were engaging and fun to do, lots of access to support and materials

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Zoom success: the guest lecturers! They were amazing!

Having visiting artists and our own work time in class worked really well over Zoom. I found the breaks we took throughout the class helpful, as it would have otherwise been a long stretch of time to sit still. It's a bit difficult to complete critiques over Zoom when you can't see a work in person, but I am unsure that there is technology that can get around the shortfalls.

providing course materials and reimagining sculpture projects to be conducive to construction in the home (as opposed to a proper workshop) was great, professor was accommodating and responsive to student needs, really compassionate and approachable teaching team

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Yes, especially if you miss making things in your day-to-day

as a physics major, this course was a great way to take a break from super challenging classes and enjoy having high-level intellectual/philosophical discussions in a safe, low-stakes environment. we got to discuss a lot of social justice/moral/philosophical implications of artwork and course discussion evolved organically, but it didnt have the same level of stress and pressure that similar discussions would carry in a writing-intensive class. it was well rounded and the readings were manageable, engaging, and really interesting to interact with. a great class. this was a wonderful way to feel well rounded in my education without worrying about grade outcomes.
